trans-unit.source: URL-decodes string and writes the result to io.
URL-decodes string as x-www-form-urlencoded and writes the result to io.
URL-decodes a string and writes the result to io.
URL-encodes string and writes the result to io.
URL-encodes string and writes the result to an IO.
URL-encodes string as x-www-form-urlencoded and writes the result to io.
Unboxes a Void* into an object of type T.
Unboxes a Void* into an object of type T. Note that for this you must specify T: Box(T).unbox(data).
Underlying IOs might have a different status.
Underscores are allowed at the beginning of a variable name, but these names are reserved for the compiler, so their use is not recommended (and it also makes the code uglier to read).
Underscores can be used to make some numbers more readable:
Unicode case folding, which is more far-reaching than Unicode case mapping.
Union is special in that it is a generic type but instantiating it might not return a union type:
Union of classes and structs under the same hierarchy
Union of named tuples with the same keys
Union of tuples of the same size
Union. Returns a Regex that matches any of patterns.
Union. Returns a Regex that matches either of the operands.
Union: returns a new set containing all unique elements from both sets.

Unless follow_symlinks is set to true, then the owner symlink itself will be changed, otherwise the owner of the symlink destination file will be changed. For example, assuming symlinks as foo -> bar -> baz:
Unless specified, the resuling binary will have the same name as the source file minus the extension .cr.

Unlike #in, which always preserves the same instant in time, #to_local_in adjusts the instant such that it results in the same local date-time representation. Both instants are apart from each other by the difference in zone offsets.
Unlike C, Int32 and MyInt are not interchangeable:
Unreserved characters are ASCII letters, ASCII digits, _, ., - and ~.
Unsafe wrapper around a Pointer that allows to write values to it while advancing the location and keeping track of how many elements were written.
Unsafely reinterprets the bytes of an object as being of another type.
Upgrades this response, writing headers and yieling the connection IO (a socket) to the given block.

Upgrades this response, writing headers and yieling the connection IO (a socket) to the given block. The block must invoke #close afterwards, the server won't do it in this case. This is useful to implement protocol upgrades, such as websockets.
Usage for casting to a bigger type
Usage for when the compiler can't infer the type of a block
Use standard coding style so your project will be navigable and readable to others.
Use :nodoc: to hide public declarations from the generated documentation. Private and protected methods are always hidden.
Use #clone if you want a deep copy.
Use #dup if you want a shallow copy.
Use #dup if you want a shallow copy.
Use JSON.build, which uses JSON::Builder, to generate JSON by emitting scalars, arrays and objects:

Use JSON.mapping to define how an object is mapped to JSON, making it the recommended easy, type-safe and efficient option for parsing and generating JSON. Refer to that module's documentation to learn about it.
Use #to_rfc3339 to format a Time according to .
Use Zip::Writer, which writes zip entries sequentially to any IO.
Use bin/crystal to run your crystal files.
Use ditto to use the same comment as in the previous declaration.
Use two spaces to indent code inside namespaces, methods, blocks or other nested contexts. For example:

Use a tuple. If you use {"crystal", "ruby", "java"} in the above program it will work the same way, but since a tuple doesn't involve heap memory it will be faster, consume less memory, and give more chances for the compiler to optimize the program.
Use string interpolation instead of concatenation
Use the #io method to read from it.
Use the #open method to read from it.
Use the IO of the parent process.
Use the third person: Returns the number of horns this unicorn has instead of Return the number of horns this unicorn has.
Use this method to release resources allocated by external libraries that are not directly managed by Crystal garbage collector.
Use this setter to provide a custom formatter. The Logger will invoke it with the following arguments:
Use this tool to unify code styles and to submit documentation improvements to Crystal itself.
Users can be retrieved by either username or their user ID:
Users can define their own annotations using the annotation keyword, which works similarly to defining a class or struct.
Using %x in the above example, we declare a variable whose name is guaranteed not to conflict with local variables in the current scope.
Using Void is the same, but Nil is more idiomatic: Void is preferred in C bindings.
Using a dash inside <...> either eliminates previous indentation or removes the next newline:
Using the shorter syntax to assign an instance variable from a method argument has the same effect:
Using these two, we can compile a program in a Mac that will run on that Linux like this:
Using tuples is the preferred way.
Using, for example, Int32 as a type restriction makes the method only accept instances of Int32:

Usually the macro def_hash can be used to generate this method. Otherwise, invoke #hash(hasher) on each object's instance variables to accumulate the result:
Utilize Crystal's built-in code formatter to automatically format all .cr files in a directory.
Valid range for seconds is 0..315_537_897_599. For nanoseconds it is 0..999_999_999.
Valid value ranges for the individual fields:
Validates an expectation and fails the example if it does not match.
Validates an expectation and fails the example if it matches.
Value too large to be stored in data type
Values are parsed using the regular .new(pull : JSON::PullParser) method.

Values from the monotonic clock and wall clock are not comparable. This method does not return a Time instance but a Time::Span amounting to the number of nanoseconds elapsed since the unspecified starting point of the monotonic clock. The returned values are strictly linearly increasing.
Values start with the value 0 and are incremented by one, but can be overwritten.
Values that don't correspond to an enum's constants are allowed: the value will still be of type Color, but when printed you will get the underlying value:
Values that don't correspond to an enum's constants are allowed: the value will still be of type Color, but when printed you will get the underlying value:

Values with binary measurements such as computer storage (e.g. RAM size) are typically expressed using unit prefixes based on 1024 (instead of multiples of 1000 as per SI standard). This method by default uses the IEC standard prefixes (Ki, Mi, Gi, Ti, Pi, Ei, Zi, Yi) based on powers of 1000 (see BinaryPrefixFormat::IEC).
Variables declared in a program are not visible inside methods:
Variables declared inside the begin part of an exception handler also get the Nil type when considered inside a rescue or ensure body. For example:
Variables exposed by a C library can be declared inside a lib declaration using a global-variable-like declaration:
Various bug workarounds that should be rather harmless. This used to be 0x000FFFFF before 0.9.7
Verifies a password against the hash.
Verifies that all dependencies are installed and requirements are satisfied.
WARNING: The behavior of SO_LINGER is platform specific.
WARNING: The behavior of SO_LINGER is platform specific. Bad things may happen especially with nonblocking sockets. See Cross-Platform Testing of SO_LINGER by Nybek for more information.
Waits for this process to complete and closes any pipes.

Warning: MD5 is no longer a cryptographically secure hash, and should not be used in security-related components, like password hashing. For passwords, see Crypto::Bcrypt::Password. For a generic cryptographic hash, use SHA-256 via OpenSSL::Digest.new("SHA256").

Warning: MD5 is no longer a cryptographically secure hash, and should not be used in security-related components, like password hashing. For passwords, see Crypto::Bcrypt::Password. For a generic cryptographic hash, use SHA-256 via OpenSSL::Digest.new("SHA256").

Warning: SHA1 is no longer a cryptographically secure hash, and should not be used in security-related components, like password hashing. For passwords, see Crypto::Bcrypt::Password. For a generic cryptographic hash, use SHA-256 via OpenSSL::Digest.new("SHA256").

Warning: SHA1 is no longer a cryptographically secure hash, and should not be used in security-related components, like password hashing. For passwords, see Crypto::Bcrypt::Password. For a generic cryptographic hash, use SHA-256 via OpenSSL::Digest.new("SHA256").
We can define a become_older method that accepts a number indicating the years to grow:
We can quickly see that @age is an integer, but we don't know the type of @name. The compiler could infer its type from all uses of the Person class. However, doing so has a few issues:
We can simplify our constructor by using a shorter syntax for assigning a method argument to an instance variable:
We can then type check against instances of these classes with not only their class, but the included modules as well:
We can use a channel for this:
We can use this function like this:

We can't do much with person, so let's add some concepts to it. A Person has a name and an age. In the "Everything is an object" section we said that an object has a type and responds to some methods, which is the only way to interact with objects, so we'll need both name and age methods. We will store this information in instance variables, which are always prefixed with an at (@) character. We also want a Person to come into existence with a name of our choice and an age of zero. We code the "come into existence" part with a special initialize method, which is normally called a constructor:
We checkout the latest version of the compiler written in Ruby, and from that compiler we compile the next versions until the current one.
We create a .o file in the target system and from that file we create a compiler.
We get an error because the compiler now treats @pet as an Animal+, which includes Animal. And since it can't find a talk method on it, it errors.
We have two accounts (each represented by a name and an amount of money).
We love C's efficiency for running code.
We love Ruby's efficiency for writing code.
We may also raise an exception in the body of the transaction:
We should forget about small efficiencies, say about 97% of the time: premature optimization is the root of all evil. Yet we should not pass up our opportunities in that critical 3%.
We want the best of both worlds.
We want the compiler to understand what we mean without having to specify types everywhere.
Weak Reference class that allows a referenced object to be garbage-collected.
What the compiler doesn't know is that for us, Animal will never be instantiated as it doesn't make sense to instantiate one. We have a way to tell the compiler so by marking the class as abstract:
What's the right way to do this? Change the expression so that it is of the right type: Array(Foo) (see example above).

When DB::Database is opened an initial number of initial_pool_size connections will be created. The pool will never hold more than max_pool_size connections. When returning/releasing a connection to the pool it will be closed if there are already max_idle_pool_size idle connections.

When spec is included, every object has the instance methods #should and #should_not. These methods are invoked on the value being tested with an expectation as argument. If the expectation is met, code execution continues. Otherwise the example has failed and other code in this block will not be executed.
When n is 0 or not given, uses the match of the entire Regex. Otherwise, uses the match of the nth capture group.
When n is 0, returns the match for the entire Regex.
When with_seconds is false, seconds are omitted; when :auto, seconds are omitted if 0.
When a case expression is a tuple literal there are a few semantic differences if a when condition is also a tuple literal.

When a connection is established it usually means opening a TCP connection or Socket. The socket will handle one statement at a time. If a program needs to perform many queries simultaneously, or if it handles concurrent requests that aim to use a database, it will need more than one active connection.
When a database is opened with crystal-db there is already a connection pool working. DB.open returns a DB::Database object which manages the whole connection pool and not just a single connection.
When a literal is assigned to an instance variable, the literal's type is added to the set. All literals have an associated type.

When a macro is invoked you can access the current scope, or type, with a special instance variable: @type. The type of this variable is TypeNode, which gives you access to type information at compile time.

When a macro is invoked you can access the method, the macro is in with a special instance variable: @def. The type of this variable is Def unless the macro is outside of a method, in this case it's NilLiteral.

When a method specifies a splat (explained in the next section), named arguments can't be used. The reason is that understanding how arguments are matched becomes very difficult; positional arguments are easier to reason about in this case.
When a new Crystal version is released you can upgrade Crystal using:
When a new Crystal version is released you can upgrade your system using:
When a program starts, it fires up a main fiber that will execute your top-level code. There, one can spawn many other fibers. The components of a program are:
When a splat method argument has no name, it means no more positional arguments can be passed, and next arguments must be passed as named arguments. For example:

When a variable's type combines different types under the same class hierarchy, its type becomes a virtual type. This applies to every class and struct except for Reference, Value, Int and Float. An example:

When an -l option is passed to the linker, it will lookup the libraries in paths passed with the -L option. CRYSTAL_LIBRARY_PATH, /usr/lib, and /usr/local/lib are added by default. Custom paths can be passed using ldflags: @[Link(ldflags: "-Lvendor/bin")].
When an expression like Type.new(...) is assigned to an instance variable, the type Type is added to the set.
When building Crystal code with the --release flag on FreeBSD, the --no-debug flag should be added too in order to avoid LLVM assertion errors.
When calling a C function that expects a pointer you can also pass nil instead of using Pointer.null to construct a null pointer.
When calling a C function you can also pass nil instead of constructing a null pointer with this method.
When capturing blocks, the type of the arguments and return type must be specified in the capturing method block signature.
When compiling for a windows target, this is equal to Path.windows(), otherwise Path.posix is used.
When creating an empty array you must always specify T:

When creating an instance, the parser is positioned in the first event. To get the event kind invoke #kind. If the event is a scalar you can invoke #value to get its string value. Other methods like #tag, #anchor and #scalar_style let you inspect other information from events.
When data is read from io it will print something akin to the following on STDERR:
When executing statements using db.query, db.exec, db.scalar, etc. the algorithm goes:

When implementing new(ctx : YAML::ParseContext, node : YAML::Nodes::Node) to deserialize an object from a node, Reference types must invoke both #read_alias and #record_anchor in order to support parsing recursive data structures.

When invoking a method on a union type, the language checks that the method exists and can be resolved (typed) for each type in the union. For this reason, adding instance methods to Union makes no sense and has no effect. However, adding class method to Union is possible and can be useful. One example is parsing JSON into one of many possible types.
When invoking a method without a receiver, like add(1, 2), it will be searched for in the program if not found in the current type or any of its ancestors.
When invoking a method, the algorithm to match call arguments to method arguments is:
When libraries are installed from Git repositories, the repository is expected to have version tags following a semver-like format, prefixed with a v. Examples: v1.2.3, v2.0.0-rc1 or v2017.04.1
When matching a regular expression using #=~ (either String#=~ or Regex#=~), the returned value will be the index of the first match in the string if the expression matched, nil otherwise.
When matching a regular expression using #match (either String#match or Regex#match), the returned value will be a Regex::MatchData if the expression matched, nil otherwise.

When parsing a request, the server keeps track of the amount of total bytes consumed for all headers (including line breaks). If combined byte size of all headers is larger than the permitted size, the server responds with the status code 432 Request Header Fields Too Large (see HTTP::Status::REQUEST_HEADER_FIELDS_TOO_LARGE).
When reading values from the database there is no type information during compile time that crystal can use. You will need to call rs.read(T) with the type T you expect to get from the database.
When reading zip files, CRC32 checksum values are automatically verified when finishing reading an entry, and Zip::Error will be raised if the computed CRC32 checksum does not match.

When specifying a type, all elements in a tuple must match that type. Additionally, the empty-tuple doesn't match any of the above cases. If you want to support the empty-tuple case, add another overload:

When substitution is performed, any backreferences found in replacement will be replaced with the contents of the corresponding capture group in pattern. Backreferences to capture groups that were not present in pattern or that did not match will be skipped. See Regex for information about capture groups.
When there are capture groups having same name, it returns the last matched capture group.
When there are many arguments, the order of the names in the invocation doesn't matter, as long as all required arguments are covered:
When they're defined inside a class or module scope it is easier to use self instead of the class name.
When this device is opened using File.open, read operations will always return EOF, and any data written will be immediately discarded.
When this is a TTY device, sync will be true for it at the start of the program.
When used in an if in conjunction with a variable, is_a?, responds_to? or nil? the compiler will restrict the types accordingly:
When using blocks with yield, the blocks are always inlined: no closures, calls or function pointers are involved. This means that this:
When using mutable data types as keys, changing the value of a key after it was inserted into the Hash may lead to undefined behaviour. This method re-indexes the hash using the current key values.

When we check to see if a particular regular expression describes a string, we can say that we are performing a match or matching one against the other. If we find that a regular expression does describe a string, we say that it matches, and we can refer to a part of the string that was described as a match.

When working with databases, it is common to need to group operations in such a way that if one fails, then we can go back to the latest safe state. This solution is described in the transaction paradigm, and is implemented by most database engines as it is necessary to meet ACID properties (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) ACID
When writing custom types, always be sure to override to_s(io), not to_s, and avoid creating intermediate strings in that method. For example:

When writing macros (especially outside of a macro definition) it is important to remember that the generated code from the macro must be valid Crystal code by itself even before it is merged into the main program's code. This means, for example, a macro cannot generate a one or more when expressions of a case statement unless case was a part of the generated code.
Whether the collection contains any cookies.
Whether the method accepts a block or not
Whether the process is still registered in the system.
Whether the process is still registered in the system. Note that this returns true for processes in the zombie or similar state.
Whether this process is already terminated.
Whether to close the enclosed IO when closing this reader.
Whether to close the enclosed IO when closing this writer.

While a pointer is unsafe because no bound checks are performed when reading from and writing to it, reading from and writing to a slice involve bound checks. In this way, a slice is a safe alternative to Pointer.
While command literals may prove useful for simple script-like tools, special caution is advised when interpolating user input because it may easily lead to command injection.
While this fiber is waiting this time, other ready-to-execute fibers might start their execution.
With alias you can give a type a different name:

With Colorize you can change the fore- and background colors and text decorations when rendering text on terminals supporting ANSI escape codes. It adds the colorize method to Object and thus all classes as its main interface, which calls to_s and surrounds it with the necessary escape codes when it comes to obtaining a string representation of the object.
With a block, an HTTP::Client::Response body is returned and the response's body is available as an IO by invoking HTTP::Client::Response#body_io.
With a buffered channel, invoking send won't switch to another fiber unless the buffer is full:
With the toggle method you can temporarily disable adding the escape codes. Settings of the instance are preserved however and can be turned back on later:
With this in mind, we present the following example:
Within replacement, the special match variable $~ will not refer to the current match.
Within a describe block, concrete test cases are defined with it . A descriptive string is supplied to it describing what the test case tests specifically.
Within a class, separate method definitions, constants and inner class definitions with one newline. For example:
Within the format string, any characters other than format specifiers (specifiers beginning with %) are copied to the result.
Without a block, an HTTP::Client::Response is returned and the response's body is available as a String by invoking HTTP::Client::Response#body.
Without arguments or parentheses, previous_def receives the same arguments as the method's arguments. Otherwise, it receives the arguments you pass to it.
Without arguments or parentheses, super receives the same arguments as the method's arguments. Otherwise, it receives the arguments you pass to it.
Wraps an IO by calculating a specified digest on read or write operations.
Wraps around exceptions re-raised from concurrent calls. The original exception can be accessed via #cause.
Write documentation to express the purpose of your code and support the crystal docs generator.
Writes (streams) zip entries to an IO.
Writes JSON into the given IO.
Writes JSON into the given IO. A JSON::Builder is yielded to the block.
Writes XML into the given IO.
Writes XML into the given IO. An XML::Builder is yielded to the block.
Writes YAML into the given IO.
Writes YAML into the given IO. A YAML::Builder is yielded to the block.
Writes a formatted string to this IO.
Writes a formatted string to this IO. For details on the format string, see Kernel::sprintf.
Writes a raw value, considered a scalar, directly into the IO without processing.

Writes a raw value, considered a scalar, directly into the IO without processing. This is the only method that might lead to invalid JSON being generated, so you must be sure that string contains a valid JSON string.
Writes a representation of the scanner.
Writes a single byte into this IO.
Writes a single byte into this IO.
Writes a slice of UTF-8 encoded bytes to this IO, using the current encoding.
Writes a string representation of the set to io.
Writes a string. The given value is first converted to a String by invoking to_s on it.
Writes an object's field and then invokes the block.
Writes an object's field and then invokes the block. This is equivalent of invoking #string(value) and then invoking the block.
Writes an object's field and value.
Writes an object's field and value. The field's name is first converted to a String by invoking to_s on it.
Writes at most slice.size bytes from slice into the wrapped IO.
Writes at most slice.size bytes from slice into the wrapped IO. Returns the number of bytes written.
Writes at most slice.size bytes from slice into the wrapped IO.
Writes at most slice.size bytes from slice into the wrapped IO. Returns the number of bytes written.
Writes the base64-decoded version of data to io.
Writes the base64-decoded version of data to io. This will decode either the normal or urlsafe alphabets.
Writes the base64-encoded version of data to io.
Writes the base64-encoded version of data to io. This method complies with RFC 2045. Line feeds are added to every 60 encoded characters.
Writes the base64-encoded version of data using a urlsafe alphabet to io.
Writes the base64-encoded version of data using a urlsafe alphabet to io. This method complies with "Base 64 Encoding with URL and Filename Safe Alphabet" in RFC 4648.
Writes the base64-encoded version of data with no newlines to io.
Writes the base64-encoded version of data with no newlines to io. This method complies with RFC 4648.
Writes the contents of slice into this IO.
Writes the contents of slice into this IO.
Writes the contents of the environment to io.
Writes the end of an array.
Writes the end of an object.
Writes the given object into this IO.
Writes the given object into this IO. This ends up calling to_s(io) on the object.
Writes the given object to this IO followed by a newline character.
Writes the given object to this IO using the specified format.
Writes the given objects into this IO by invoking to_s(io) on each of the objects.
Writes the given objects, each followed by a newline character.
Writes the given string to this IO followed by a newline character unless the string already ends with one.
Writes the start of an array, invokes the block, and the writes the end of it.
Writes the start of an array.
Writes the start of an object, invokes the block, and the writes the end of it.
Writes the start of an object.
Writes this complex object to an io, surrounded by parentheses.
Writes this complex object to an io.
Writes this float to the given io in the given format.
Writes this float to the given io in the given format. See also: IO#write_bytes.
Writes this integer to the given io in the given format.
Writing a program in a single file is OK for little snippets and small benchmark code. Big programs are better maintained and understood when split across different files.
Yielded by Benchmark#bm, use #report to report benchmarks.
Yields self to the block, and then returns self.
Yields self. Nil overrides this method and doesn't yield.
Yields a Multipart::Builder to the given block, returning the generated message as a String.
Yields a CSV::Row to append a row.
Yields a CSV::Row to append a row. A newline is appended to IO after the block exits.
Yields a block with the chunks in the given size.
Yields a context object with an #update(data : String | Bytes) method available.
Yields a context object with an #update(data : String | Bytes) method available. Returns the resulting digest afterwards.
Yields a context object with an #update(data : String | Bytes) method available. Returns the resulting digest in hexadecimal representation afterwards.
Yields all files that match against any of patterns.
Yields an IO to read this entry's contents.
Yields an IO to read this entry's contents. Multiple entries can be opened and read concurrently.
Yields an HTTP::Params::Builder to add extra parameters other than those defined by the standard.
Yields an IO to read a section inside this IO.
Yields an IO to read a section inside this file.
Yields an IO to read a section inside this file. Multiple sections can be read concurrently.
Yields an IO::Memory to read a section of this IO's buffer.
Yields an IO that can be used to append to the epilogue of the multipart message.
Yields an IO that can be used to append to the epilogue of the multipart message. Throws if #finish is called before this method, or no body parts have been appended.
Yields an IO that can be used to append to the preamble of the multipart message.
Yields an IO that can be used to append to the preamble of the multipart message. Throws if #body_part is called before this method.
Yields an IO that can be used to write to a body part which is appended to the multipart message with the given headers.
Yields an IO that can be used to write to a body part which is appended to the multipart message with the given headers. Throws if #finish or #epilogue is called before this method.
Yields each HTTP::Cookie in the collection.
Yields each byte in the string to the block.
Yields each char for the downcase equivalent of this char.
Yields each char for the upcase equivalent of this char.
Yields each char in this string to the block, returns the number of times the block returned a truthy value.
Yields each char in this string to the block.
Yields each char in this string to the block. Returns a new String with all characters for which the block returned a truthy value removed.
Yields each char in this string to the block. Returns a new String, that has all characters removed, that were the same as the previous one and for which the given block returned a truthy value.
Yields each character and its index in the string to the block.
Yields each character in the string to the block.
Yields each codepoint to the block.
Yields each component of this path as a String.
Yields each element in this iterator together with its index.
Yields each element of the set, and returns self.
Yields each entry in the zip to the given block.
Yields each index of self to the given block and then assigns the block's value in that position.
Yields each index of self to the given block and then assigns the block's value in that position. Returns self.
Yields each index of self, in the given range, to the given block and then assigns the block's value in that position.
Yields each index of self, in the given range, to the given block and then assigns the block's value in that position. Returns self.
Yields each index of self, starting at from and just count times, to the given block and then assigns the block's value in that position.
Yields each index of self, starting at from and just count times, to the given block and then assigns the block's value in that position. Returns self.
Yields each index of self, starting at from, to the given block and then assigns the block's value in that position.
Yields each index of self, starting at from, to the given block and then assigns the block's value in that position. Returns self.
Yields each item in this deque, from first to last.
Yields each key and value in this named tuple.
Yields each key and value, together with an index starting at offset, in this named tuple.
Yields each key in this named tuple.
Yields each key-value pair in this mapping.
Yields each line in filename to the given block.
Yields each of a CSV's rows as an Array(String).
Yields each of the bytes of this char as encoded by UTF-8.
Yields each of the elements in this tuple in reverse order.
Yields each of the elements in this tuple.
Yields each of the remaining rows as an Array(String).
Yields each parent of this path beginning with the topmost parent.

Yields each possible Addrinfo resolution since a domain may resolve to many IP. Implementations are supposed to try all the addresses until the socket is connected (or bound) or there are no addresses to try anymore.
Yields each possible permutation of size of self.
Yields each value in this named tuple.
Yields elements of self and others in tandem to the given block.
Yields successive characters from #string starting from #pos.
Yields the current element at the given index and updates the value at the given index with the block's value.
Yields the current element at the given index and updates the value at the given index with the block's value. Raises IndexError if trying to set an element outside the array's range.
You can require code defined in other files:
You can actually pass a proc to a method that yields:
You can also declare constants inside a lib declaration:
You can also define attributes for each property.
You can also initialize some fields with a syntax similar to named arguments:
You can also install the latest nightly build by using the edge channel.
You can also make a struct behave like a C union (this can be pretty unsafe):
You can also pass an RGB color to colorize:
You can also rescue multiple exception types at once by specifying a union type:
You can also set the Entry's time (which is Time.utc by default) and extra data before adding it to the zip stream.
You can also spawn by passing a method call instead of a block. To understand why this is useful, let's look at this example:
You can also specify many fields of the same type:
You can also use "../" to access parent directories relative to the current file, so require "../../foo/bar" works as well.
You can also use an OAuth2::Session to automatically refresh expired tokens before each request.
You can also use the &block syntax to forward blocks, but then you have to at least specify the input types, and the generated code will involve closures and will be slower:
You can assign the same value to multiple variables using chained assignment:
You can bind to variadic functions:
You can check if a flag is defined with the flag? macro method:
You can choose the Entry's compression method before adding it.
You can compile and run specs from folder trees, individual files or specific lines in a file.
You can declare/assign multiple variables at the same time by separating expressions with a comma (,):
You can define local variables without the need to specify their type:
You can define an operator for a type like this:
You can easily create strings with embedded content, known as string interpolation. The language comes with other syntax as well to create arrays, hashes, ranges, tuples and more:
You can invoke a fixed subset of methods on AST nodes at compile-time. These methods are documented in a fictitious Crystal::Macros module.

You can invoke a fixed subset of methods on AST nodes at compile-time. These methods are documented on the classes in this module. Additionally, methods of the Macros module are top-level methods that you can invoke, like #puts and #run.
You can invoke a method on the case's expression in a when by using the implicit-object syntax:
You can invoke a superclass' method using super:
You can invoke the previously redefined method with previous_def:
You can iterate a finite amount of times:
You can make a type restriction take the type of an argument, or part of the type of an argument, using forall:
You can manipulate ARGV yourself to control what ARGF operates on. If you remove a file from ARGV, it is ignored by ARGF; if you add files to ARGV, ARGF will read from it.
You can obtain pointers in four ways: #new, #malloc, pointerof and by calling a C function that returns a pointer.
You can omit the parentheses if the function doesn't have arguments (and omit them in the call as well):
You can override methods in a derived class:
You can pass a block to this macro, that will be inserted inside the struct definition.
You can read multiple columns at once:
You can read this document from top to bottom, but it’s advisable to jump through sections because some concepts are interrelated and can’t be explained in isolation.
You can see that @pet is Animal+. The + means it's a virtual type, meaning "any class that inherits from Animal, including Animal".

You can specify the value of a member:
You can specify type restrictions in splats:
You can think an && as syntax sugar of an if:
You can think an || as syntax sugar of an if:
You can think of a NamedTuple as an immutable Hash whose keys (which are of type Symbol), and the types for each key, are known at compile time.
You can think of a Tuple as an immutable Array whose types for each position are known at compile time.
You can use break to break out of a while loop:
You can use next to try to execute the next iteration of a while loop. After executing next, the while's condition is checked and, if truthy, the body will be executed.
You can use self.class to restrict to the Person type. The next section talks about the .class suffix in type restrictions.
You can use a backslash followed by an u and four hexadecimal characters to denote a unicode codepoint written:
You can use a backslash to denote some characters:
You can use a special array literal syntax with other types too, as long as they define an argless .new method and a #<< method. Set is one such type:
You can use an enum as a type in a fun argument or struct or union members:
You can use code blocks, or simply blocks, which are a very convenient way to reuse code and get some features from the functional world:
You can use function types in C declarations:
You can't dynamically create symbols. When you compile your program, each symbol gets assigned a unique number.
You can, as always, define a constructor for your exception or just use the default one.
You can, of course, use receive inside a spawned fiber:
You create an instance of a class by invoking new on that class:
You may limit the DNS resolution time with dns_timeout and limit the connection time to the remote server with connect_timeout. Both values must be in seconds (integers or floats).
You may use then after the when condition to place the body on a single line.
You might want to take a look at the available configuration flags first:
You must copy this .o file to that system and execute those commands. Once you do this the executable will be available in that target system.
You program by invoking methods (or sending messages) to objects.
You raise exceptions by invoking a top-level raise method. Unlike other keywords, raise is a regular method with two overloads: one accepting a String and another accepting an Exception instance:
You should also be careful when working on mutable types inside of the struct:
You should never have to deal with this class. Instead, use String.build.
You should never invoke this method unless you need to redefine C's main function. See Crystal.main for more details.
You should never use this method unless chr turns out to be a bottleneck.

You shouldn't always use a struct, though. Structs are passed by value, so if you pass one to a method and the method makes changes to it, the caller won't see those changes, so they can be bug-prone. The best thing to do is to only use structs with immutable objects, especially if they are small.
You typically use this to display a help message. The default raises InvalidOption.
You typically use this to display a help message. The default raises MissingOption.
You typically use this to get the main arguments (not modifiers) that your program expects (for example, filenames)
